questions.question: A 60-year-old man who has worked in the zinc mines presents to his urologist with urinary symptoms, including increased frequency, hesitancy, and nocturia. During a digital rectal examination, he is found to have an enlarged prostate with a palpable nodule. Which environmental exposure is most likely associated with his prostate cancer risk?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Cadmium Explanation: Occupational exposure to cadmium, commonly found in industries such as zinc mining, smelting of zinc ores, and battery manufacturing, has been associated with an increased risk of prostate cancer. The body accumulates cadmium through inhalation of dust and fumes containing cadmium particles. Zinc (Option A) Zinc is an essential trace element important for prostate health, excessive zinc exposure does not have a direct association with prostate cancer. Benzopyrene (Option B): Benzopyrene, a polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) present in tobacco smoke and combustion products, is associated with increased risks of lung cancer, bladder cancer, skin cancer, and other malignancies. Arsenic (Option C): Prolonged exposure to arsenic can occur through contaminated water, soil, and food, commonly by the use of arsenic-based pesticides and herbicides. It is associated with an increased risk of developing skin, lung, bladder, and liver cancers. Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic basis of disease 10th edition, page 321, 414

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with vinyl chloride exposure?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Hepatic angiosarcoma Explanation: Hepatic angiosarcoma is a high-grade vascular malignancy and is the most common sarcoma arising in the liver, especially in those with significant exposure to Vinyl chloride. It is more common in men and occurs in the elderly. Some other risk factors include arsenic, anabolic steroids, radiation, and thorium dioxide (Thorotrast). Hepatocellular carcinoma (Option A) Hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common primary liver cancer and is typically associated with cirrhosis, chronic hepatitis B or C infections due to HBV or HCV, alcohol abuse, or non-alcoholic fatty liver disease and not associated with exposure to vinyl chloride. Cholangiocarcinoma (Option C) Cholangiocarcinoma (carcinoma of the biliary duct in the liver) includes conditions that lead to chronic inflammation of the bile ducts, such as Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), liver fluke infections such as Clonorchis and Opisthorcis, or certain jbiliary tract disorders. It is not associated with vinyl chloride exposure . Focal nodular hyperplasia (Option D) Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is the second most common benign liver lesion after hepatic hemangioma. It consists of hyperplastic hepatocytes surrounding a central scar, which can result from altered blood flow. FNH is more prevalent in women and is associated with hormonal imbalances but not with vinyl chloride exposure. Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic basis of disease 10th edition, page 522

questions.question: A 16-year-old girl presents with a clear-cell vaginal tumour. Upon further inquiry, it was revealed that her mother has a history of taking medication during pregnancy to prevent premature labour. Which medication is most likely associated with the development of this tumour in the daughter?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) DES (Diethylstilbestrol) Explanation: In the given scenario, the clear cell vaginal tumour in the daughter is most likely linked to DES (Diethylstilbestrol). DES, a synthetic estrogen previously administered to pregnant women to prevent miscarriages and pregnancy complications, has been associated with a significantly increased risk of clear cell adenocarcinoma of the cervix or vagina in daughters exposed to it in utero. Thalidomide (Option B): Thalidomide, once used to treat morning sickness in pregnant women, caused severe birth defects like limb deformities (phocomelia), blindness, deafness, heart issues, and brain damage in their babies. It is a teratogen, not a carcinogen. Tamoxifen (Option C): Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator used in the treatment of ER-positive breast cancer. While it is associated with an increased risk of endometrial cancer in women who take it for breast cancer treatment, it's not linked to clear cell vaginal tumours in their daughters. Medroxyprogesterone acetate (Option D): It is a synthetic progestin commonly used in hormonal therapies and contraceptives. Long-term use or high doses of MPA, particularly in combination with estrogen, may increase the risk of breast cancer. However, maternal use of it is not typically associated with vaginal tumours in daughters. Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic basis of disease 10th edition, page 321, 994

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indirect-acting carcinogen?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Nitrosoureas Explanation: Nitrosoureas is a direct-acting carcinogenic agent. Characteristic Direct-Acting Carcinogens Indirect-Acting Carcinogens Mode of action Directly damage DNA, leading to mutations Require metabolic conversion to become active (ultimate carcinogens) Carcinogenic potency Typically weak More potent Endogenous enzymes involved None Cytochrome P-450 enzymes play a key role Examples Alkylating agents (Anti-cancer drugs) like nitrosoureas, cyclophosphamide Acylating agents Aromatic hydrocarbons like benzo[a]pyrene Aromatic Amines, Amides, Azo Dyes (Option B) Natural Plant and Microbial Products like Aflatoxin B1, Griseofulvin, and Betel nuts (Options A, D) Insecticides, fungicides Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic basis of disease 10th edition, Page 321, 322

questions.question: Which of the following radiations is the most common cause of skin cancer?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) UV-B radiation Explanation: UV-B radiation is the major cause of sunburn and skin cancer. These medium wavelengths (280-320 nm) primarily affect the outer layers of the skin and are highly mutagenic. It is responsible for inducing the formation of pyrimidine dimers within DNA, leading to mutations that can result in various types of skin cancer, including squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma, and melanoma. Fair-skinned individuals are at higher risk. UV-A radiation (Option A): UV-A rays are longer wavelengths (320-400 nm) and penetrate deeper into the skin. They primarily cause skin ageing. UV-A radiation, particularly in combination with UV-B, can increase the risk of skin cancer. UV-C radiation (Option C) These shorter wavelengths (200-280 nm) are extremely potent in terms of DNA damage, but they are largely filtered out by the Earth's ozone layer and do not reach the surface in significant amounts. UV-D radiation (Option D): The UV spectrum typically consists of UV-A, UV-B, and UV-C and no UV-D radiation. Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic basis of disease 10th edition,Page 323

questions.question: A 55-year-old female radiology technician with 25 years of occupational exposure to diagnostic X-rays and fluoroscopy presents with a three-month history of increasing fatigue, unintentional weight loss, and frequent infections. Which cancer type is most likely associated with her occupational history?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Acute Myeloid Leukemia Explanation: Due to prolonged exposure to ionising radiation the patient is at an increased risk of developing Acute Myeloid Leukemia (M/C cancer in individuals with exposure to ionising radiation). Ionising radiation, which includes electromagnetic (x-rays, γ rays) and particulate ( α particles, β particles, protons, neutrons) radiations, is carcinogenic. It can cause cancer by directly damaging cellular DNA, leading to mutations that disrupt normal gene function and structure. Leukaemia often has a relatively short latent period, typically around 7 years or less after exposure to certain factors like radiation or chemicals. Solid tumours like breast, colon, thyroid, and lung cancers generally have longer latent periods compared to leukaemia. Pancreatic cancer (Option B): Risk of Pancreatic cancer is more associated with cigarette smoking, heavy alcohol drinking, obesity, and diet (high intake of saturated fat and/or meat, particularly smoked or processed meats). Medullary thyroid cancer (Option C): Medullary thyroid cancer is primarily associated with genetic factors, specifically mutations in the RET proto-oncogene, rather than radiation exposure. However, the risk of Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid and Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid have a high association with radiation exposure. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (Option D): Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) is the only leukaemia not associated with radiation exposure. Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic basis of disease 10th edition, Page 323

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents for a routine gynaecological examination. Her Pap smear and biopsy reveals abnormal cells suggestive of cervical dysplasia. Further, HPV testing indicates the presence of specific HPV types associated with cervical cancer. Which HPV types are most commonly linked to an increased risk of cervical cancer in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) High-risk 16, 18 Explanation: The abnormal cells in the pap smear and biopsy are known as Koilocytes characterised by a raisinoid nucleus and a perinuclear halo, which indicates HPV infection. High-risk HPV types like HPV 16 and HPV 18 are strongly linked to a higher risk of cervical cancer, including high-grade cervical dysplasia and invasive cancer. Low-risk HPV types such as HPV 6 and HPV 11 are often associated with genital warts such as condyloma acuminatum and low-grade changes in cervical cells (Option A). 16- Most common 18- Most specific Integration of viral DNA within the E1/E2 open reading frame disrupts the E2 viral repressor gene, leading to increased expression of the HPV E6 and E7 oncogenes. Integration of high-risk HPV DNA is a critical step in the oncogenic process, distinguishing it from low-risk HPV infections. Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic basis of disease 10th edition, page 324

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman with regular menstrual cycles undergoes routine Pap smear screening, which reveals a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) of the cervix. Further testing confirms infection with high-risk HPV type 16. Which of the following mechanisms regarding the oncogenic activity of E6 and E7 of HPV is correct?

options.A: E6 protein inhibits the degradation of p53.
options.B: E6 stimulates the expression of TERT.
options.D: E7 can inactivate cyclins A and E

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) E6 stimulates the expression of TERT. Explanation: E6 and E7 proteins from high-risk HPV types exhibit increased affinity for key cellular regulatory proteins (e.g., p53, RB) compared to low-risk HPV types. This enhanced affinity allows high-risk HPV-infected cells to evade tumour suppressor mechanisms, dysregulate cell cycle control, and promote oncogenic transformation. Oncogenic Activities of E6 Protein Oncogenic Activities of E7 Protein Binds to and promotes degradation of p53 → Impairs cell growth and apoptosis regulation (Option A). Stimulates expression of TERT (telomerase reverse transcriptase) → Facilitates cellular immortalisation by maintaining telomere length. Disrupts interaction between RB protein and E2F transcription factors Inactivates CDK inhibitors (e.g., p21 and p27) (Option C). Activates cyclins A and E (Option D) All these mechanisms enhance cell cycle progression and cellular proliferation in HPV infections.

questions.question: A 10-year-old girl presents with rapidly growing jaw swelling and pain. Further examination reveals bilateral enlargement of the mandible and maxilla. Biopsy suggests the presence of a starry-sky appearance as shown in the image. Which of the following infectious agents is most commonly associated with the pathogenesis of this malignancy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) EBV Explanation: The ‘starry sky pattern’ of histopathology represents scattered macrophages with phagocytosed cell debris among proliferating lymphoma cells is characteristic of Burkitt lymphoma. Burkitt Lymphoma: Burkitt lymphoma is an aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. It is most commonly associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, which is endemic in central Africa and New Guinea, where it is the most common childhood tumour. EBV, a DNA oncogenic virus, infects epithelial cells of the oropharynx and B-cells via the CD21 molecule on their surface. Its LMP-1 (latent membrane protein-1) gene activates NF- κβ and JAK/STAT pathways, promoting B-cell survival and proliferation, increasing the risk of B-cell lymphoma. questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding H. pylori infection and its association with malignancies is correct ?

options.A: Gastric lymphomas associated with H. pylori infection are primarily of B-cell origin.
options.B: H. pylori strains associated with gastric adenocarcinomas contain the cytotoxin-associated B gene.
options.C: VacA, a toxin from H. pylori, causes gastric cell apoptosis, reducing cancer risk.
options.D: MALT lymphomas associated with t(11;18) translocation respond to anti-H.Pylori therapy.

questions.explanation: origin. Correct Answer: A) Gastric lymphomas associated with H. pylori infection are primarily of B-cell origin. Explanation: H. pylori, the first bacterium classified as a carcinogen, is associated with gastric adenocarcinomas and lymphomas, including MALT lymphomas of B-cell origin. Gastric adenocarcinomas arise due to increased epithelial cell proliferation in chronic inflammation caused by H. pylori infection. Pathogenicity genes like CagA (cytotoxin-associated A) trigger uncontrolled growth factor pathways. (Option B) H. pylori produces a bacterial toxin VacA, inducing apoptosis in gastric epithelial cells and influencing cancer development. (Option C) Chronic H. pylori infection leads to polyclonal B-cell proliferation triggered by H. pylori-reactive T cells, which contribute to the development of MALT lymphomas. Antibiotic therapy can eradicate H. pylori and "cure" MALT lymphomas by removing the antigenic stimulus for T cells . But, MALT lymphomas associated with t(11;18) translocation are resistant to anti-H.Pylori therapy. (Option D) Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic basis of disease 10th edition, Page 327

questions.question: Match the following carcinogens with the respective cancer risk 1. Azodyes a) Urothelial carcinoma of the bladder 2. Schistosoma haematobium b) AML & ALL 3. Radon c) Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder 4. Benzene d) Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1-a, 2-c, 3- d, 4-b Explanation: Risk factor Cancer risk Azodyes/ Beta naphthyl amine/Benzidine Urothelial carcinoma/ Transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder Schistosoma haematobium Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder Radon Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung Benzene AML & ALL Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic basis of disease 10th edition, Pages 321-327 https://www.uptodate.com /contents/cigarette-smoking-and-other-possible-risk-factors-for-lung-cancer?search=lung%20cancer%20epidemiol ogy&source=search_result&selectedTitle=1%7E150&usage_type=default&display_rank=1#H21310588 https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/6741759/
